coredata.dc:title: XANES and EXAFS in gaseous Mo (CO)6
coredata.dc:creator: Tronc, Michel
Dezarnaud-Dandine, Christine
coredata.dc:description:
Abstract
X-ray absorption near-edge structure (XANES) and extended X-ray absorption fine structure (EXAFS) have been observed in the molybdenum L2,3 edge absorption spectrum of Mo(CO)6 in the gas phase at room temperature, with a direct ion-yield technique at the LURE Super ACO storage ring in Orsay. Molecular shape resonances are identified and weak oscillations in both the 2p
3 2
and 2p
1 2
continua are interpreted as EXAFS oscillations due to the CO ligands.

xocs:doc.xocs:rawtext: Volume 184, number 4 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LEYI ERS 27 September 1991 XANES and EXAFS in gaseous Mo(CO)6 Michel Tronc and Christine Dezarnaud-Dandine Laboratoire de Chimie Physique Universite Pierre ei Marie Curie, li rue Pierre et Marie Curie, 75231 Paris Cedex 05, France and LURE. Laboratoire CNRS-CEA-MEN, Universite de Paris-Sud, 91405 Orsay, France Received 25 June 1991 X-ray absorption near-edge structure (XANES) and extended X-ray absorption fine structure (EXAFS) have been observed in the molybdenum L23 edge absorption spectrum of Mo(CO)6 in the gas phase at room temperature, with a direct ion-yield technique at the LURE Super ACO storage ring in Orsay. Molecular shape resorances are identified and weak oscillations in both the 2p312 and 2p~ continua are interpreted as EXAFS oscillations due to the CO ligands. 1. Introduction Transition metal carbonyl complexes are a con- stant center of interest: they have been studied with a variety of experimental techniques [l 4] and the- oretically [5 7] both as a fundamental goal to un- derstand better the metal CO bonding in free mol- ecules and in adsorbates on metals, and because of their practical role in surface chemistry, in catalysis and in biochemistry. If the occupied levels are well known from photo- electron spectroscopy [I], information about un- occupied valence levels is still scarce. Recent exper- imental results concern both high-resolution inner- shell ~ O~~) excitation at the ligand [8 11], ob- tained by inner-shell electron-energy-loss spectros- copy (ISEELS) in dipole simulated conditions and metal core excitation [12,131. The X-ray absorption near-edge structure (XANES) are understood in terms of molecular shape resonances in which the core electron is trapped in an unoccupied valence level and probe the metal ligand bonding and the CO bond modification in the complexes through the analysis of the vibrational structure in the Cis~_~z*(CO) spectra [8,91. Unoccupied levels have also been recently probed with the formation of temporary negative-ion shape resonances (TN!) observed in low-energy electron- AssocieauCNRSUA 176. transmission spectroscopy (ETS) [14 16]. In both XANES and ETS resonances, the final-state wavefunctions at the resonance energies are con- fined inside the molecule behind a potential barrier which results from the balance between attractive Coulomb and correlation-polarization forces and re- pulsive centrifugal forces associated with the high-i components of the final-slate wavefunction, or from the effective potential barrier created by electroneg- ative cage atoms. Molybdenum L edge X-ray absorption spectra have been obtained for a great variety of compounds in aqueous solutions, amorphous materials, lyophulized samples, single cryslals and enzymes [171. They have been analyzed in terms of ligand-field theory, and reflect the unfilled Mo d-level splitting and chemical effects (oxidation state, nature of ligands ...) [17]. Besides these spectroscopie studies, structural infor- mation has been obtained from extended X-ray ab- sorption fine structure (EXAFS) on a great variety of mono- and di-nuclear molybdenum complexes for both aqueous solutions and finely powdered solid samples [18]. But while both XANES and EXAFS are very sensitive to the stereochemical environment of the absorbing atom, they resort to different the- oretical models, and while the extraction of bond lengths is well established and widely used from EXAFS [19,20], the influence of bond length on XANES is mainly based on an empirical rule [21,22] which has been criticized [23]. However, recent 267 0009-2614/91/S 03.50 1991 Elsevier Science Publishers BY. All rights reserved, 27September 1991 Volume 184, number 4 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS minimal-basis set molecular-orbital energy calcula- tions [24] correlate valence and K-shell photoioni- zation resonances with bond lengths and clarify the origins of this correlation. Both XANES and EXAFS are attributable to the modification of the wavefunction final-state ampli- tude in the core of the ionized atom, resulting from high-/ components of the escaping electron interact- ing with the molecular field which is very sensitive to the local environment. The lower members of the high-/ component sequence would exhibit the shape resonance effect while higher members are mani- fested as EXAFS oscillations [25,26]. The purpose of the present work is to study both XANES and EXAFS in the metal L-shell excitation spectrum of a highly symmetric octahedral transi- tion metal complex Mo(CO)6 in the gas phase in or- der to be free from long-range order (metal metal interaction) and to stimulate theoretical work to con- nect XANES and EXAFS theoretical approaches, and their role in the local structure determination. 2. Experimental The Mo 2P3/21/2 spectrum of gaseous Mo(CO)6 was recorded with a double-crystal monochromator (Ge 111) using in situ total ionization yield tech- nique [27] at the LURE SACO storage ring in Or- say. In general, the number of ions produced per photon absorbed varies over the spectrum because below-edge features lead predominantly to singly charged ions when above-edge s lead in many cases to dissociative double (or higher) photoionization via Coulomb explosion reactions. Nevertheless, the equivalence of ionization yield with true photoab- sorption was demonstrated in our experimental con- ditions both below and above the S ls ionization threshold around 2.500 eV in a variety of sulfur- atom-containing molecules [27,28]. The absorption spectrum was normalized to the incident photon flux measured simultaneously. The absolute energy pho- ton scale was calibrated relative to the t shape res- onance at 2486.0 eV in the S ls absorption spectrum of SF6. The molybdenum hexacarbonyl was obtained from Strem Chemicals Inc. and used without further pu- nfication. Due to its low vapor pressure, the solid sample was simply allowed to seblime in the gas cell at ambient temperature. The pressure was measured with a capacitance manometer and stable around 0.2 Torr. The experimental resolution (~t0.8 eV) was smaller than the natural widths of a Mo 2p hole (1.6 1.8 eV) dominated by Auger decay for the 2P3/2 hole and Auger plus Coster Kronig decays for the 2P1/2 hole [29,30]. 3. Results and discussion The molybdenum 2P3(2, 1/2 core-excitation spec- trum of gaseous Mo (CO ) 6 obtained at a pressure of 0.2 Torr is presented in fig. 1. The energies, binding energies of the core excited states (i.e. the so-called term values, TVs) and proposed assignments of ob- served features are reported in table 1. As the 2p IPs have not yet been measured in Mo(CO)6, the 2P3/2 and 2P1/2 IPs given in table 1 have been estimated by considering a constant en- ergy difference between the XPS 3d512 and 2P3/2 core ionization energies in the free Mo atom [31] and in the Mo(CO)6 cluster and using the same 2P3/2 2P1/2 spin orbit splitting of 104.3 eV in free Mo and in Mo(CO)6. These estimated IP values may be er- roneous but they allowed a relative TV scale (table 1) for comparison of the two spin orbit split series. Excitation to MOs having large metal 4d character are expected to dominate the Mo 2p core-excitation XANES spectrum, together with excitation to virtual MUs built mainly from the CO ligand ~ orbitais. The 2P312 and 2PI/2 spin orbit components of the Mo(CO)6 spectrum are similar in shape with equal TYs (table 1). Each component exhibits a strong feature (white line) 2.4 eV below the respective L edge, and with relative intensities of nearly two in agreement with statistical degeneracy of the L3 and L2 ion cores in the absence of atomic multiplet effects. After correction for broadening from monochro- mator resolution, the two white lines have similar widths (2.4 0.1 eV) at variance with features ob- served in the L2,3 excitation spectrum of 3d transi- tion metal carbonyls where the L2 lines are always broader because of the L2L3M Coster Kronig pro- cess reducing the core hole lifetime [12], and in L23 spectra of 4d transition metal complexes [13,17] 268 Volume 184, number 4 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 27 September 1991 C J .th o >- u) z Ui I z Table I Energies (E, eV), term values (TV, eV) and proposed assignments for features in the molybdenum 2P312.l/2 excitation spectrum of gaseous Mo(CO)6 Mo 2P3/2 Mo 2Pi~~ Assignment No. E:tO.2 TV No. E O.2 TV 1 2525.4 2527.8 2.4 1 2629.7 2632.1 2.4 4d(eg+t2g) IP a) 2 2533.2 5.4 2 2637.4 5.3 c*(M0C) double excit. cd maximum 3 2541.4 13.6 3 2645.6 13.5 EXAFS 4 2573.4 45.6 4 2677.8 45.7 EXAFS 5 2619 91.2 5 2724 91.9 EXAFS ~ Estimated (see text). where the linewidth broadening and splitting is ac- counted for on the basis of final-state multiplet split- ting. These 2.4 eV widths are broader than expected from 2p hole lifetime (1.6 1.8 eV) [29] probably because of the unresolved small ligand-field splitting of the 4d orbital into an e5 doubly degenerate and a t2g triply degenerate set of orbitaIs in octahedral sym- metry. An alternative explanation for the broad sin- gle-band aspect of these two white lines spin orbit components may be an unresolved contribution from a low-energy Mo 2p ~4d transition and a high-en- ergy 2p ~CO ligand tt~ charge-transfer band as re- cently proposed on the basis of extended Huckel cal- culation (EHT) in the equivalent ionic-core virtual orbital model ((Z+ 1) analogy) for cobalt com- plexes [32]. The TYs (2.4 eV) are smaller than that observed in metal 2p, carbon ls, and nitrogen ls ex- citation spectra of 3d transition metal complexes (TV=4.5 5.5 eV) [8,9,12,13]. It may be due to a wrong estimate of the IPs and (or) to the composite nature of these features containing a low-energy peak component at a TV of 5 eV. Mo(2P 3J~)1 M~ 1CO)~ Mo 2p j I i I i I I 251JU 2550 2600 2650 2700 ENERGY (sV) 2750 2800 Fig. I. Mo 2p~~ excitation spectrum ofgasenus Mo(CO)6. The hatched lines indicate the estimated 2p IPs (see text). 269 27September 1991 Volume 184, number 4 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS The low-intensity peaks just above the corre- spondinglPs (TV= 5.4 eV) may result from dou- ble excitation, delayed c d maximum or c~ (Mo C)- type shape resonance [9]. No low-intensity pre-main peak structure can be observed in Mo(CO)6 (fig. 1) contrary to the L23 X-ray absorption-edge spectra of a series of 3dN (N= 0 8) transition metal ionic compounds well re- produced by a theoretical analysis based on atomic multiplet theory with the inclusion of the crystal field [33 35]. This is probably a consequence of a smaller multipole interaction for a 4d transition metal and a larger spin orbit splitting [36]. The L3 and L2 continuum of Mo(CO)6 are dom- inated by broad oscillations (fig. 1) assigned to EXAFS interferences of the ejected 2p electron with the wave backscattered by the in-line C and O atom pairs. The two peaks with TV = 13.6 eV may con- tain a co*(CO) shape-resonance contribution. 4. Conclusion We have observed XANES and EXAFS in the 2p X-ray absorption edges of gaseous Mo(CO)6. XANES and EXAFS calculations on Mo(CO)6 and other 4d transition metal complexes will be pub- lished in a forthcoming paper. Acknowledgement We thank A.M. Flanck, P. ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para:
X-ray absorption near-edge structure (XANES) and extended X-ray absorption fine structure (EXAFS) have been observed in the molybdenum L2,3 edge absorption spectrum of Mo(CO)6 in the gas phase at room temperature, with a direct ion-yield technique at the LURE Super ACO storage ring in Orsay. Molecular shape resonances are identified and weak oscillations in both the 2p
3 2
and 2p
1 2
continua are interpreted as EXAFS oscillations due to the CO ligands.
